snippet.textDisplay: Re not working on floppy disks: curses! I do work decoding old floppy disk formats (<plug> http://cowlark.com/fluxengine </plug>) and being able to see the data would be really useful. Or maybe just interesting. Incidentally, regarding the fluid, I ran into someone who used it non-destructively on floppy disks by placing a sheet of cellophane over the disk and applying the fluid to the cellophane. It's thin enough not to disturb the signals but keeps the fluid off the disk. Sadly the fluid is stupidly expensive and you only get to use it once, so I've never bothered.
snippet.textOriginal: Re not working on floppy disks: curses! I do work decoding old floppy disk formats (<plug> http://cowlark.com/fluxengine </plug>) and being able to see the data would be really useful. Or maybe just interesting. Incidentally, regarding the fluid, I ran into someone who used it non-destructively on floppy disks by placing a sheet of cellophane over the disk and applying the fluid to the cellophane. It's thin enough not to disturb the signals but keeps the fluid off the disk. Sadly the fluid is stupidly expensive and you only get to use it once, so I've never bothered.

snippet.textDisplay: Try checking a prerecorded 4-track tape. Machines never seem to be adjusted to place the tracks equally spaced across the tape. The space between the tracks should ideally be equal. But alignment instructions tell you to have the top of the heads pole piece just slightly above the edge of the tape. This results in what we see here, and causes increased playback interference from the adjacent track. Which you hear faintly playing, backwards. So it would be interesting on a prerecorded tape. One of the other products used to view tracks on tape is a liquid called Magna-See made by Soundcraft a division of CBS Records. I have a can of this, which I've had since sometime in the 80's. I used it to check track placement on 9-track computer tape. The tape is dipped into the liquid and the solvent evaporates  leaving behind a very find dust of iron particles showing the tracks. And it doesn't harm the tape or data on the tape. You just wipe it off and the tape is just fine. This also will show the tracks on a VHS tape, Beta too. And yes, I repair and collect reel to reel machines. And perfection is always the goal. And hang onto that full track width tape. Can be used to adjust head azimuth if lacking a very expensive calibration tape.
snippet.textOriginal: Try checking a prerecorded 4-track tape. Machines never seem to be adjusted to place the tracks equally spaced across the tape. The space between the tracks should ideally be equal. But alignment instructions tell you to have the top of the heads pole piece just slightly above the edge of the tape. This results in what we see here, and causes increased playback interference from the adjacent track. Which you hear faintly playing, backwards. So it would be interesting on a prerecorded tape. One of the other products used to view tracks on tape is a liquid called Magna-See made by Soundcraft a division of CBS Records. I have a can of this, which I've had since sometime in the 80's. I used it to check track placement on 9-track computer tape. The tape is dipped into the liquid and the solvent evaporates  leaving behind a very find dust of iron particles showing the tracks. And it doesn't harm the tape or data on the tape. You just wipe it off and the tape is just fine. This also will show the tracks on a VHS tape, Beta too. And yes, I repair and collect reel to reel machines. And perfection is always the goal. And hang onto that full track width tape. Can be used to adjust head azimuth if lacking a very expensive calibration tape.

snippet.textDisplay: This is fantastic; I get analog tapes to transfer all the time, and it's almost always a guessing game as to which format has been used.  Most consumers "back in the day" just didn't know enough to at least mark the box.  Now I can "Look" at the tape itself and know ahead of time.  Thanks for posting!
snippet.textOriginal: This is fantastic; I get analog tapes to transfer all the time, and it's almost always a guessing game as to which format has been used.  Most consumers "back in the day" just didn't know enough to at least mark the box.  Now I can "Look" at the tape itself and know ahead of time.  Thanks for posting!

snippet.textDisplay: As a Computer Field Service Engineer we used to use similar devices to check and adjust head alignment on vacuum column tape decks.  Important job to get right as if you just slapped a new head into a deck it probably wouldnt be able to read older tapes - pretty important for getting data from backup tapes!
snippet.textOriginal: As a Computer Field Service Engineer we used to use similar devices to check and adjust head alignment on vacuum column tape decks.  Important job to get right as if you just slapped a new head into a deck it probably wouldnt be able to read older tapes - pretty important for getting data from backup tapes!

snippet.textDisplay: I wonder why you couldn't see a monaural audio track at the opposite side ot the VHS tape? It is recorded in the same analogue fashion as on any other magnetic tape, with a decent track width. Maybe you've tested a silent portion of the recording. I'm not surprised you couldn't see the video recording, as it is very densely packed (one track of video is just about 58 microns wide).
snippet.textOriginal: I wonder why you couldn't see a monaural audio track at the opposite side ot the VHS tape? It is recorded in the same analogue fashion as on any other magnetic tape, with a decent track width. Maybe you've tested a silent portion of the recording. I'm not surprised you couldn't see the video recording, as it is very densely packed (one track of video is just about 58 microns wide).

snippet.textDisplay: @ 5:41 as an interesting thought experiment / programming / math / audacity exercise, I did a screen grab of a frame here from the cassette recording, reasoning as it was the slowest speed, there is the most information there to convert back into audio based on the RGB values at each point. I definitely got a sinusoidal sound-like wave pattern into audacity but not exactly what we might call music... not enough resolution in the particle patterns and too short a sample time.
snippet.textOriginal: @ 5:41 as an interesting thought experiment / programming / math / audacity exercise, I did a screen grab of a frame here from the cassette recording, reasoning as it was the slowest speed, there is the most information there to convert back into audio based on the RGB values at each point.  I definitely got a sinusoidal sound-like wave pattern into audacity but not exactly what we might call music...  not enough resolution in the particle patterns and too short a sample time.

snippet.textDisplay: Years ago I used to do forensics of floppy disks produced in duplicators my company built. I used the ferro-fluid directly on the "cookie" and could diagnose many kinds of malfunctions. That fluid was super expensive.
snippet.textOriginal: Years ago I used to do forensics of floppy disks produced in duplicators my company built. I used the ferro-fluid directly on the "cookie" and could diagnose many kinds of malfunctions. That fluid was super expensive.

snippet.textDisplay: Less messy than the rusty solvent I used to pour on tapes to see the pattern after it evaporated and left ferrous powder behind.
snippet.textOriginal: Less messy than the rusty solvent I used to pour on tapes to see the pattern after it evaporated and left ferrous powder behind.

snippet.textDisplay: In the Commodore 64 days, we used to copy tapes with cracked games. Although sometimes these didn't work, because of tape recorder head alignment differences. Which meant waiting ages for a game to load, only to get the dreaded '?LOAD ERROR'. There was a piece of software you could use to align the heads, which had output quite similar to this device. Here's a video of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUGTigzpjwk
snippet.textOriginal: In the Commodore 64 days, we used to copy tapes with cracked games. Although sometimes these didn't work, because of tape recorder head alignment differences. Which meant waiting ages for a game to load, only to get the dreaded '?LOAD ERROR'. There was a piece of software you could use to align the heads, which had output quite similar to this device. Here's a video of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUGTigzpjwk

snippet.textDisplay: Would this device be sensitive in such a way that it may get too strongly magnetized and therefore destroyed by subjecting it to a strong magnetic field, like the one of a modern neodymium magnet? No, I don't want you to try it out, don't jeopardize this rare vintage device for the sake of a question in a youtube comment. If at all, an answer like "I suspect yes" will be enough. Or if you suspect no, then try it out, but don't try it out if it destroys the device, because it is too valuable for that.
snippet.textOriginal: Would this device be sensitive in such a way that it may get too strongly magnetized and therefore destroyed by subjecting it to a strong magnetic field, like the one of a modern neodymium magnet? snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Techmoan,

I really hope you will see this message. I've been a subscriber for quite a long time and do find your videos really fascinating! I have a question for you related to Audio Cassettes: I'm currently in the possession of about 2-3 tapes (one is a rare industrial tape, the others are selfmade home recordings) that are of very high sentimental value to me since they contain private recordings of me and my brother in our early childhood years.


Is there any chance that I could make use of your tech-knowledge and have you digitize/transfer and preserve those memories into digital before it is too late and they will have deteriorated beyond restoration? I would know enough to connect a simple tape recorder to my computer and just hit play and record, but I don't know enough to get the best out of it possible, which starts with having a high-quality playback machine in the first place.


Of course, I'd be willing to pay the service as well as post costs (I'm based in Germany). Would that be an option? Looking forward to hearing back from you.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey Techmoan, 

I really hope you will see this message. I've been a subscriber for quite a long time and do find your videos really fascinating! I have a question for you related to Audio Cassettes: I'm currently in the possession of about 2-3 tapes (one is a rare industrial tape, the others are selfmade home recordings) that are of very high sentimental value to me since they contain private recordings of me and my brother in our early childhood years.


Is there any chance that I could make use of your tech-knowledge and have you digitize/transfer and preserve those memories into digital before it is too late and they will have deteriorated beyond restoration? I would know enough to connect a simple tape recorder to my computer and just hit play and record, but I don't know enough to get the best out of it possible, which starts with having a high-quality playback machine in the first place.


Of course, I'd be willing to pay the service as well as post costs (I'm based in Germany). Would that be an option? Looking forward to hearing back from you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Being a broadcast/RF engineer I'm a lot more interested in your reel to reel set up with that level visualizer top left, I've never seen one like that. I mostly deal in modern equipment but being only 29 the old equipment feels new to me when I come across it occasionally in some radio stations usually buried in a dark back room.

I get to keep a lot of old equipment I find not to replace payment but because most people want it gone or don't know how to use old equipment.
I love modern technology but there is something special about older tech that can be repaired by someone like me much more easily than say SMT parts needing specialized hot beds to solder parts.
snippet.textOriginal:
Being a broadcast/RF engineer I'm a lot more interested in your reel to reel set up with that level visualizer top left, I've never seen one like that. I mostly deal in modern equipment but being only 29 the old equipment feels new to me when I come across it occasionally in some radio stations usually buried in a dark back room.

 I get to keep a lot of old equipment I find not to replace payment but because most people want it gone or don't know how to use old equipment.
I love modern technology but there is something special about older tech that can be repaired by someone like me much more easily than say SMT parts needing specialized hot beds to solder parts.

snippet.textDisplay:
Similar idea to the iron containing fluid they used to edit Videotape in the 1950s/1960s. You had to splice VT at exactly the right point. The fluid would show up the vertical magnetic lines.
I guess this device would help you edit audio tape in a similar way?
snippet.textOriginal:
Similar idea to the iron containing fluid they used to edit Videotape in the 1950s/1960s.  You had to splice VT at exactly the right point. The fluid would show up the vertical magnetic lines. 
I guess this device would help you edit audio tape in a similar way?

snippet.textDisplay: hey, i noticed that the diameter of the tape is a lot larger when it is full vs when it is near finished.  If the tape recorder spins the tape at a consistent speed then the tape doesnt move at a constant velocity, right?  how do they deal with this?  or does it just kinda work itself out because the same thing happens when recording onto the tape?  Does the information density or quality change at all between the beginning and end of the tape?
snippet.textOriginal: hey, i noticed that the diameter of the tape is a lot larger when it is full vs when it is near finished. snippet.textDisplay: You looked at this effect for many recording mediums. What about the opposite? Could something else do the same effect? snippet.textDisplay: At first I thought it was a magnetic velvet like fabric, I'm a bit sad that it wasn't actually, I'm pretty certain I've seen non active magnetic-field-viewers based on colour instead of particle attraction though, but that is likely a much more recent development (I've seen one article about one such material from 2009 but it also references previous such materials in the article).
snippet.textOriginal: At first I thought it was a magnetic velvet like fabric, I'm a bit sad that it wasn't actually, I'm pretty certain I've seen non active magnetic-field-viewers based on colour instead of particle attraction though, but that is likely a much more recent development (I've seen one article about one such material from 2009 but it also references previous such materials in the article).

snippet.textDisplay:
You can buy "Magnetic Field Viewer Viewing Film" on ebay. I cannot say if it has the required resolution to "see" an eight track pattern, but it is cheap enough to pick up a sample and see.
https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2334524.m570.l1311.R1.TR2.TRC0.A0.H0.Xmagnetic+field+view.TRS0&_nkw=magnetic+field+viewing+film&_sacat=0&LH_TitleDesc=0&_sop=15&_osacat=0&_odkw=ferro+film
snippet.textOriginal:
You can buy "Magnetic Field Viewer Viewing Film" on ebay. I cannot say if it has the required resolution to "see" an eight track pattern, but it is cheap enough to pick up a sample and see.
